div1.p: First, my tongue-tied apologies for misunderstanding part of the "Love Cry." Still, the early & perhaps unreasoning prejudice against the 'vatic' tone of the poem, persists . . . Peccavi . . . . Surely, I feel "The Stranger at the Gate" is your most representative work, althoalthough there are several individual things in the other volumes I wouldn't want to lose. Some of those fiery little lyrics, for instance . . . But you've grown unquestionably — &, please God, you're still growing. That's one of the things that make a reading of your stuff, actually thrilling . . . .But enough — I have forsworn superlatives for this week — besides I'll think of your love for hyphens — & damp my enthusiam!

I envy you that mysterious
17
possession of epical material which is "truly American" & yet not Indian. What the devil can it be? And where (outside of Alaska or the Central American Mayas) did you get it? I'm willing to wager it's cut out of different cloth than "The Death of Aggrippina" — Eh?

By the bye, I sent your volume to a friend of mine in England who amuses himself by doing occasional reviews. In his last letter he complained of the puerile way "we Americans" handled sex. He cited, among many scornful quotations, the imitative verse of G. S. Viereck, the piffling pomposity of Cale Young Rice & a few others . . . So I sent him one of your books as a counter-blast. I hope he finds the sincerity in it that I'm sure
18
is there.

I'm sending under separate cover a few recent copies of "The Masses" of which I am one of the least efficient editors. It may provoke but I'm certain it will interest you. If the art features in particular seems wantonly 'raw' & purposely crude, do not think it is done for the mere fun of shocking (in itself a rather fascinating pastime). They are (as the magazine itself is) a protest against the merely prettifying sort of stuff that fills the usual magazine — it is in the nature of an antidote to Harrisonfisherized art, & ditto literature. We hope to make it the "Simplicissimus" of these broad (in area) states! With which ambitious & rhetorical climax I can do no more
19
than sign myself

postscript.p: I am enclosing a few recent clippings that Burrelle insists on sending me (for $5 — per year!) I wish I had some better examples to send but it's always the weaker things that keep on getting quoted — nichtwahr?
Of course there's no good reason why I should send these to you at all but my wife swears she'll sweep 'em away if they're not off any desk by to-morrow — so there you are!

div1.note: Louis Untermeyer (Reveals his bad disposition & rather mean nature even while we were still friends
